title: 113_hr5651
content: The Act titled "Small Business Hardship Relief Act" provides a hardship exemption to the employer health insurance mandate for small businesses. The "Small Business Hardship Relief Act" offers a hardship exemption for small businesses from the employer health insurance mandate under Section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Small businesses can be exempt if they demonstrate hardship by missing two or more consecutive loan payments or being a debtor in a title 11 case. The "Small Business Hardship Relief Act" provides exemptions for small businesses facing financial difficulties, such as receiving notices of utility service termination, eviction, foreclosure, property damage from disasters, or other hardships determined by the Secretary. The exemption is limited to five years. The "Small Business Hardship Relief Act" exempts small businesses from certain provisions if they have been subject to them for five previous calendar years. A small business is defined as an employer with an average of no more than 100 full-time employees in the preceding calendar year. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to months after the enactment of the Act. The hardship exemption under section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code cannot be the sole factor for auditing taxpayers. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on additional indications of business hardship to add to the list in the Code. The Secretary of the Treasury will add new hardships to the list under section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code within 6 months of the Act's enactment. A report to Congress will detail the study conducted on potential hardships, including reasons for inclusion or exclusion. The Secretary of the Treasury will add new hardships to the list under section 4980H of the Internal Revenue Code within 6 months of the Act's enactment. Any reference to the Secretary of the Treasury in this subsection includes any designee of the Secretary.
